p.s: Go to hell is what I wished to have screamed in Amir's face today!
He is my uncle, he is Muslim, but he stands on the wrong side.
And he doesn't even see it himself?
Therefore he'll probably go to hell anyways.
Did I ever see him wear his Kifur, this Mr. Kapoor?
I believe he never set a foot in a mosque since he moved to the US, either.
Sometimes I wonder if it would be best to move OUT OF the US.
Especially now, when these unbelievable authorities (fuck them) might take that decision from me anyways.
As much as I despise Amir and his hostile view on his own people, somehow he touched me for a moment today.
There's a reason you father came here.He wanted to make a better life for himself and his family or something along the lines is what he said to me.
I don't like to admit it, but I think I might have forgotten that aspect a bit lately.
Their sacrifices.
Am I too selfish?
But then again - it is not my fault that the US society is such a shitshow.
If I could live here as a Muslim peacefully and as free as I wanted to, I wouldn't go, for sure.
He'll stay, I know that.
He is always afraid, I know that won't change.
But I am not afraid!
And I don't need no Ken, no lawyer to speak for me.
I can speak up for myself!
Emily saw that.
She might be a bitch, but I'd give her that - she saw me for me.
Not like Amir who closes his eyes and ignores my identity.
And she didn't deserve that beating, either.
I think I'll go to Pakistan - but not until I have put up with a fight.
A big one.
Maybe with the help of the media?
I want to show the world who Hussein Abdullah is.
And that you can't force a whole ethnicity out of your country with violence.
Not with me!
Not while I'm watching!

And then, one day, when I'll sit teethless in a fabric company in Pakistan (How knows?) I might stumble over a rock on the street after work and I will look up to the man who offered me his hands and it will be Amir.
We'll drink tea together, like the old times.
Who knows?
Maybe he'll come to his senses after all?
